metadata.title: Berg Balance Scale •The patient is instructed to complete 14 different tasks that challenge balance. Gait items are not included in the scale. In most items, the patient is asked to maintain a given position for a specific time. Points are deducted if: –the time or distance requirements are not met –the patient’s performance warrants supervision –the patient touches an external support or receives assistance from the examiner •A copy of the BBS can be obtained online from the Internet Stroke Center website, http://www.strokecenter.org/professionals/stroke-diagnosis/stroke-assessment-scales/ , or at https://cdn.ymaws.com/ www.fpta.org/resource/resmgr/imported/Balance%20Assessements.pdf
description: The Berg Balance Scale (BBS) is by far the most commonly used balance assessment.(1) This test was developed by Katherine Berg primarily for use with older adults. Subsequently, the BBS has been administered to patients with conditions that affect balance such as stroke,(1) Parkinson disease,(2) spinal cord injury,(2,3,4) and a variety of other disorders(5)
The BBS is a 14-item  scale that quantitatively assesses balance and risk of falls in community-dwelling  older adults through direct observation of their performance(6)
The BBS measures the patient’s ability to maintain balance statically or while performing self-initiated  functional movements for a specified duration of time

ICD-10 codes.C69-C72: Neoplasms of brain and other parts of central nervous system

R00-R99.base: Symptoms and signs involving the nervous and musculoskeletal systems
R00-R99.R29: Other symptoms involving the nervous and musculoskeletal systems

ICD-10 codes.W00-W19: Slipping, tripping, stumbling and falls (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

CPT codes.97750: Physical performance test or measurement, with written report

reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies are applicable for this assessment, and no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
contraindications precautions to test: Patients undergoing this test are at increased risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and provide appropriate guarding/assistance to ensure the patient’s safety while administering this test
This test should not be used if it cannot be completed safely or if the patient’s cognition and/or mental status prevents him or her from adequately following instructions
potential complications adverse effects: Subjects need to understand that they must maintain their balance while attempting the tasks. The choices of which leg to stand on or how far to reach are left to the subject. Poor judgment will adversely influence the performance and the scoring

Weaknesses of the BBS that have been identified include a higher average time to administer the test (compared to the POMA-B)  and an inability to detect changes in gait(23) –Within a cohort of acute post-stroke  patients, the Static Balance Test was found to be equally valid, more reliable, and to take much less time than the BBS, so may be more appropriate for use in acute stroke care, especially for daily routine testing(36)

Authors of a study conducted in the United States suggest that the linguistic complexity of the BBS may limit its validity for assessing patients with aphasia(37) –Persons with aphasia performed significantly better on a modified version of the BBS that reduced linguistic complexity and added visual and written cues along with modeling and repetition compared to their performance on the BBS –This indicates that at least some of their performance difficulty was likely due to poor auditory comprehension of test instructions rather than true balance difficulty
test preparation materials required: Two chairs – one with arms, one without; stool for sitting without back support; stopwatch; ruler; step
test procedure: The patient is instructed to complete 14 different tasks that challenge balance. Gait items are not included in the scale. In most items, the patient is asked to maintain a given position for a specific time. Points are deducted if: –the time or distance requirements are not met –the patient’s performance warrants supervision –the patient touches an external support or receives assistance from the examiner

A copy of the BBS can be obtained online from the Internet Stroke Center website, http://www.strokecenter.org/professionals/stroke-diagnosis/stroke-assessment-scales/ , or at https://cdn.ymaws.com/ www.fpta.org/resource/resmgr/imported/Balance%20Assessements.pdf
test scoring interpretation: Items are scored from 0 to 4, with a score of 0 representing inability to complete the task and 4 representing ability to complete the task independently
Total possible score is 56 points, with higher scores indicating better balance ability

A total score of 0 to 20 represents balance impairment (which may indicate wheelchair dependence), 21 to 40 represents acceptable balance (which may indicate walking with assistance), and 41 to 56 represents good (independent) balance
Individuals 69 years old without any health conditions likely to affect mobility can be expected to have a BBS score of 56/56(31)

Results of a systematic review with meta-analysis  indicate that healthy community-dwelling  older adults have modest balance deficits as measured by the BBS(25) –BBS scores decline and become more variable with increasing age(25)
Normal rate of decline is 0.75 points per year after age 69(31)
In SCI, BBS scores are not associated with the number of falls and the BBS is not able to discriminate fallers from nonfallers(3)

The BBS is based on subjective assessment by the physical therapist and provides information about balance at that particular moment, so is not suitable for continuous fall-risk  evaluation in free-living situations(38)
